title: Workflow for Simple test of the swarm concept
description:
```json
{
  "title": "Swarm Test: 'The Coffee Shop Competitor Spy' – Track 10 Cafés in Real-Time Without Lifting a Finger",
  "description": "Imagine you’re the manager of a trendy café in Portland, where customers *obsess* over who has the best avocado toast, fastest Wi-Fi, and most Instagram-worthy latte art. Right now, you’re stuck refreshing 10 competitor café websites every morning to check their menus, prices, and specials—wasting 45 minutes of your day. What if you could *deploy a swarm of virtual browsers* to monitor all 10 cafés simultaneously, alerting you instantly when a competitor drops their price on a signature dish or adds a new seasonal item? This workflow turns your daily grind into a 2-minute glance at a dashboard, so you can focus on what matters: perfecting your own menu and keeping customers hooked. No more FOMO (Fear of Missing Out) on competitor moves.",
  "use_case": "Small business owners (e.g., café managers, boutique shop owners, local service providers) who need to monitor 5-20 competitors daily for pricing, promotions, or inventory changes—but *hate* manual data collection. This is for the person who’s tired of missing out on sales because a competitor undercut them or launched a promotion they didn’t know about.",
  "steps_overview": [
    "Step 1: **Deploy the Swarm** – Launch 10 lightweight BrowserOS agents (think of them as tiny, disposable browsers) to silently visit each competitor’s website. *Why this matters*: Instead of opening 10 tabs and refreshing manually, the swarm does it in parallel, cutting time from 45 minutes to 2 minutes. Each agent mimics a real user with random delays to avoid detection.",
    "Step 2: **Target the Right Data** – Configure each agent to extract *only* the critical data: menu items (name, price, description), daily specials, operating hours, and any promotional badges (e.g., ‘BOGO 50% off’). *Why this matters*: You’re not scraping *everything*—just the 5-10 data points that directly impact your decisions. Example: If ‘Avocado Toast’ is your bestseller, prioritize tracking its price at every café.",
    "Step 3: **Add a ‘Change Detector’** – Set up a rule: *‘Alert me if any price drops by >10% or if a new item appears in the “Specials” section.’* *Why this matters*: You’ll stop wasting time on static data (e.g., a café’s ‘About Us’ page) and focus on *actionable* changes that require a response.",
    "Step 4: **Simulate User Behavior** – Have each agent scroll, hover over items, and even ‘click’ to expand sections (like a real customer). *Why this matters*: Some websites hide key info (e.g., shipping costs or calorie counts) behind interactive elements. The swarm mimics human behavior to uncover these details automatically.",
    "Step 5: **Handle ‘Noisy’ Websites** – Add logic to skip pop-ups, ignore cookie consent banners, and bypass ‘We’ve detected a bot’ traps. *Why this matters*: Competitors often block scrapers, but a swarm with human-like behavior slips through undetected. Example: If a café’s site has a CAPTCHA, the agent retries with a new IP or user agent.",
    "Step 6: **Aggregate Data in Real-Time** – Feed the extracted data into a shared spreadsheet or dashboard (e.g., Google Sheets, Airtable) with color-coded alerts. *Why this matters*: No more copying-pasting. The swarm updates your single source of truth automatically, so you can sort, filter, and analyze trends in seconds.",
    "Step 7: **Schedule ‘Deep Dives’** – Once a week, deploy the swarm to run a *full audit* of competitor websites, including checking for new menu items, updated photos, or changes in customer reviews. *Why this matters*: This catches long-term trends (e.g., ‘Competitor X added a vegan menu—should we?’) that daily checks might miss.",
    "Step 8: **Add a ‘Competitor Mood Ring’** – Use the swarm to track sentiment from public reviews (e.g., ‘Most complaints about slow service at Café Y’). *Why this matters*: Price isn’t everything. If a competitor’s reviews tank, you might want to poach their customers with a targeted promo—*before* they leave for good."
  ],
  "input_required": [
    "Specific input #1: **Competitor URLs** – The exact web addresses of the 5-20 cafés/businesses you’re tracking (e.g., `https://thebrewbarista.com/menu`, `https://avocadoandcoffee.com/specials`). *Why you need this*: The swarm needs a starting point. Pro tip: Include URLs for their *menu*, *specials*, and *reviews* pages if they’re separate.",
    "Specific input #2: **Data Fields to Track** – A list of *exactly* what matters to you, like: ‘Price of ‘Chocolate Croissant’, ‘Daily Special Name’, ‘Operating Hours’, ‘Wi-Fi Password (if listed publicly)’. *Why this matters*: The swarm will only extract what you specify, saving time and avoiding clutter. Example: If you don’t care about ‘Contact Us’ info, don’t include it.",
    "Specific input #3: **Alert Thresholds** – Define what changes trigger an alert (e.g., ‘Price drop >10%’, ‘New item in Specials’, ‘Review score <3.5’). *Why this matters*: You’ll avoid alert fatigue. Example: ‘Only notify me if a competitor’s latte price drops below $3.50.’",
    "Specific input #4: **Your Dashboard** – A Google Sheet, Airtable, or Notion doc where you want the data dumped. *Why this matters*: The swarm needs a home for its findings. Example: Share a link to your ‘Competitor Tracker’ sheet where the swarm can append new data."
  ],
  "output_produced": [
    "Tangible output #1: **Live Competitor Dashboard** – A Google Sheet or Airtable with tabs for each café, updated every 30 minutes. Columns include: *Item Name*, *Price*, *Special? (Yes/No)*, *Change Since Last Check*, *Alert Status (⚠️ if threshold met)*. *How to use it*: Sort by ‘Price’ to spot the cheapest options instantly or filter by ‘Alert Status’ to see what needs your attention.",
    "Tangible output #2: **Daily Alert Digest** – A Slack message or email with *only* the changes that matter (e.g., ‘Café Z dropped their croissant price to $2.99—15% cheaper than you!’). *How to use it*: Reply ‘A’ to the alert to auto-generate a counter-offer script for your staff (e.g., ‘Tell customers: “We’ll match that price today only!”’).",
    "Tangible output #3: **Weekly Trend Report** – A PDF or shared doc summarizing: *‘Competitor X added 3 new items this week; Y removed their happy hour.’* *How to use it*: Use this in your team meeting to brainstorm responses (e.g., ‘Should we add a happy hour to compete?’)."
  ],
  "estimated_duration": "2 minutes to set up the swarm (one-time), then 30 seconds daily to review alerts. For 10 competitors, the initial deployment takes ~5 minutes, but it runs autonomously afterward. Scales linearly: Add 5 more competitors? Just 1 extra minute of setup.",
  "difficulty": "intermediate",
  "tags": [
    "competitive-intelligence",
    "small-business",
    "real-time-monitoring",
    "price-tracking",
    "local-competitor-analysis",
    "swarm-automation",
    "cafe-retail",
    "alert-based-workflows"
  ],
  "real_world_applications": [
    "Detailed scenario #1: **The Portland Café Manager** – Sarah runs a popular café and was losing customers to a new competitor who kept undercutting her prices. After deploying the swarm, she caught the competitor’s mistake: they *accidentally* listed a daily special at half-price for a week. She matched it, drove foot traffic, and turned the competitor’s error into a $2,000 sales boost. *ROI*: 3 hours/week saved × 4 weeks = 12 hours/month reclaimed for menu innovation.",
    "Detailed scenario #2: **The Boutique Owner’s Secret Weapon** – Emma owns a small boutique and was frustrated by Amazon and Etsy sellers copying her product designs. She used the swarm to monitor 15 competitors’ websites for new listings matching her items. When she spotted a knockoff, she’d email her lawyer with screenshots—*before* the competitor gained traction. *ROI*: 5 infringements caught early, saving her $
use_case: Simple test of the swarm concept
